botanical_details.genus: Phlox may be evergreen or herbaceous, mat-forming or erect perennials or shrubs, with simple leaves and salver-shaped flowers in terminal clusters

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in fertile, humus-rich, moisture-retentive soil in full sun, and every autumn add a thick mulch of organic material to help preserve soil moisture
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division in autumn or spring, by basal cuttings in spring or by root cuttings from early autumn to spring; root cuttings are the best method to ensure healthy plants
how_to_grow.pruning: Deadhead to prolong flowering; cut down to the base in late autumn and remove the cut stems, to reduce the risk of eelworm and mildew the following year
how_to_grow.pests: Generally pest-free but may be susceptible to slugs, snails, aphids, and phlox stem eelworm
how_to_grow.diseases: Generally disease-free but may be susceptible to crown gall, leafy gall, fungal leaf spot, verticillium wilt, and powdery mildews
